properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme wind chill values of -45 to -50 are expected to occur overnight and into the morning hours for portions of northern Manitoba. These wind chill values will moderate throughout the day on Tuesday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T13:23:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T21:24:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2157278518.2019
Area: Brochet, Tadoule Lake, Lynn Lake, Leaf Rapids, Pukatawagan, South Indian Lake and Amisk Prov. Park, Split Lake and York Landing, Thompson Thicket Portage and Pikwitonei, Nelson House
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 15 to 20 cm of snow will fall between this morning and Tuesday morning as a warm front moves across the area. For the Prince George region, area highways will likely see more snow than the city so travellers are advised to exercise caution. Some areas may see a brief break in the snow early this afternoon but the snow will resume late this afternoon and end tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T05:11:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T13:12:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3039747520.2019
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel, Stuart - Nechako, Prince George, McGregor
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries, heavy at times, and local snow squalls will continue. Visibilities will be significantly reduced in areas of heavy snow and blowing snow with very strong winds. Total snowfall: locally 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: northern Cape Breton. Time span: today until this evening. Remarks: Strong and cold westerly winds blowing over the Gulf of St. Lawrence have caused heavy flurries with local embedded snow squalls to develop over northern Cape Breton Island including the Highlands. Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow can be expected through the day today and into the early evening. Snowfall rates will taper off later this evening, with light flurries expected to continue into Tuesday. Visibility will improve as snowfall rates and winds begin to ease. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T01:59:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T14:55:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0533140326.2019
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Further snowfall accumulations: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 80 km/h. Locations: Nain and Natuashish. Time span: continuing until this afternoon. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will continue through today in the Nain and Natuashish areas. Strong east to northeasterly winds will accompany the snow, resulting in poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions will improve as winds begin to ease this afternoon. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-16T22:59:39-00:00

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Area on 2019-12-16. Higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected near the coast today. An intense low pressure system will produce strong to high winds over the areas listed below. The combination of these winds and the current run of high amplitude tides could produce breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2019-12-16, from 03:00 PM to 07:00 PM. Matane: 2019-12-16, from 03:00 PM to 07:00 PM. Sainte-Anne-des-Monts - Grande-Vallée: 2019-12-16, from 02:30 PM to 06:30 PM. Minganie: 2019-12-16, from 02:30 PM to 06:30 PM. Anticosti: 2019-12-16, from 02:30 PM to 06:30 PM. Natashquan: 2019-12-16, from 12:30 PM to 04:30 PM. Chevery: 2019-12-16, from 12:30 PM to 04:30 PM. ### High waves combined with the surge may cause damage along the coast. Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T02:04:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T16:29:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2504967073.2019
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Minganie, Natashquan, Chevery, Anticosti
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea water levels are expected. Wave heights: 5 to 8 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: west-facing shorelines from Hawkes Bay to Port aux Basques. Time span: until early Tuesday morning. Next high tide: 1:30A.M. to 3:30A.M. Tuesday morning. Remarks: Storm surge and minor coastal flooding is possible along shorelines exposed to the west, especially near high tide tonight. Although tonight's high tide is not expected to be as high as the tide earlier this afternoon, the stronger winds and higher waves are expected to have similar impacts as experienced today. Water levels will begin to subside Tuesday morning as the tide drops. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-17T11:00:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T19:39:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4047176001.2019

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Additional snowfall: locally up to 5 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h except up 100 km/h along the coast until Tuesday morning Locations: the Connaigre, Burin, and Avalon peninsulas. Time span: through this evening. Remarks: Strong westerly winds accompanying the snow squalls will produce poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve this near midnight. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A warm front and associated low pressure centre will approach the north coast tonight. Winds will rise this evening as the warm front nears and then reach 90 km/h late this evening ahead of the low pressure centre. As the low passes overnight, winds will ease and shift to westerlies of 50 km/h. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall still possible for southwestern Nova Scotia on Tuesday night and Wednesday, less likely elsewhere. Total snowfall: possibly reaching 10 cm in the southwest, with only 2 to 5 cm now expected from Halifax eastward Locations: Atlantic coastal regions of Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday evening until noon Wednesday for Yarmouth County to Halifax Metro and Halifax County West. Wednesday morning to Wednesday evening for Halifax County - East of Porters Lake to Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County. Remarks: An approaching low pressure system is now expected to track further south of Nova Scotia than previously forecast on Tuesday night and Wednesday. Snow is still forecast to begin over southwestern Nova Scotia Tuesday afternoon and then spread eastward, reaching Cape Breton on Wednesday morning. However, total snowfall is now only expected to approach 10 cm over the South Shore from Yarmouth to Lunenburg Counties. Due to the uncertainty which remains in the forecast track, the snowfall forecast may be revised as the system approaches. In any case, this snowfall event has the potential to create difficult driving conditions in some areas during the Wednesday morning commute. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T12:00:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T20:01:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2741419381.2019
Area: Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Guysborough County, Richmond County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A warm front and associated low pressure centre will approach the north coast tonight. Ahead of the front, snow will intensify this afternoon for inland areas of the north coast. As the warm air moves onto the coast, snow will change to freezing rain at Kitimat and spread toward Terrace. Overnight, Kitimat will likely change to rain while freezing rain persists inland. At Stewart, precipitation is expected to remain as snow tonight and Tuesday morning with total snowfall amounts near 25 cm. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T11:01:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T19:02:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2935715065.2019
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Further snowfall amounts: generally 5 to 10 cm except locally 25 cm or more in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 to 100 km/h except locally as high as 110 km/h from the Port au Port Peninsula south to Port aux Basques tonight until Tuesday morning. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland, Deer Lake, and the Humber Valley. Time span: continuing until Tuesday evening. Remarks: Intense snow squalls, in conjunction with very strong westerly winds, will continue until Tuesday evening. Visibility will be frequently reduced to near zero to give blizzard like conditions in blowing snow. Little improvement is expected until winds begin to ease on Tuesday evening. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-17T11:17:51-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts; 90 km/h. Location: Coastal areas of the Acadian Peninsula. Time span: Today. Remarks: Westerly winds gusting to 90 km/h will continue today. The strongest gusts will be over exposed areas near the coast. Gusts will diminish to 70 km/h late this evening. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T06:45:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T14:46:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2993606106.2019
Area: Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Additional snowfall: locally 10 to 15 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h except up to 100 km/h along the coast until Tuesday morning. Locations: Burgeo and the Burgeo Highway. Time span: continuing until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Visibilities are expected to be near zero in snow squalls and blowing snow. Snow squalls are expected to continue to produce blizzard conditions inland along the Burgeo highway tonight. Conditions will improve along the coast this evening. Highway conditions will improve Tuesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-17T11:29:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T19:32:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1938891554.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls from Lake Superior continue this afternoon and into Tuesday. Total snowfall amounts of 15 cm are possible by morning in the strongest snow squalls. Heavy snow will make travel hazardous and visibilities reduced. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. The snow squalls are expected to drift to the south of the region tomorrow afternoon and then weaken by Tuesday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T13:01:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T21:02:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3341866085.2019
Area: Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this afternoon and evening. Snow squalls from Lake Superior continue to move through the region this afternoon and may persist through the evening. Total snowfall amounts of near 10 cm with locally higher amounts are possible in the strongest snow squalls. Heavy snow will make travel hazardous and visibilities reduced. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. The snow squalls are expected to drift south of the region tonight before returning tomorrow morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T12:55:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T20:56:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2879987995.2019
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada
